intro: Sarcocephalus parvus, commonly known as the small-headed wild bean, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its leguminous properties and often nitrogen-fixing capabilities. The plant is a shrub that typically grows to a height of about 1 to 2 meters, featuring compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. Its fruit is a legume pod that contains several small, round seeds. Sarcocephalus parvus is often found in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments.
